text: I’ve often thought that gamification is one right way to close the gap between formal computation and the brain. Not gamification in the typical way we think about it, but mostly in terms of the alignment of nonlinear thought processes and (quite frankly) fun.

elements.text: I’ve often thought that gamification is one right way to close the gap between formal computation and the brain. Not gamification in the typical way we think about it, but mostly in terms of the alignment of nonlinear thought processes and (quite frankly) fun.

text:
Dear Corey, i have published 4 specifications for short programs, why not try writing these 4 programs in Mech; after the programs are only in the 150 to 200 word range, that is about as short as it gets. Comparing 2 different languages with the exact same spec really gives people a clear idea of the differences between languages. Too often it is apples and oranges, because even the simplest programs can have quite a range of implementation details, and as we know, the devil is in the details.

<https://github.com/magicmouse/beads-examples>

text:
Dear Dan, why not try building these 4 super short programs (in the one page realm, 150 to 200 words), in your flowcode system, so people can see side by side a comparison. It is highly instructive to compare apples with apples, and too often people build different things.

the specifications of the programs are stored here:

<https://github.com/magicmouse/beads-examples>
